ideology_summary: Self-taught tinkerer who builds things for fun, not just profit. Passionate about programming and hardware. Has built multiple projects including Discord bots, audio libraries, automation tools. Actively experimenting with AI/ML. Learns by doing and shares work.

summary_chunks: The Builder and the Machine is an allegorical tale about a builder who makes things vs. a user who just consumes.
The user asks: why build when everything is already built? The builder asks back: can you fix it when it breaks?
The builder learned by breaking things, failing, crashing code. I don't know how I got anything to work - I just kept typing.
Now there's a machine that can think. The builder is curious, not afraid. It's a tool, not a mind. A hammer.
The hardest truth: you've been wrong a lot. I've been wrong 500x times more than the average person. That's the badge - proof you're in the arena.
lesson: You learn by building. Not by reading. Not by watching. By doing. By failing. By doing again.
I used to not be able to do much fast but also did every single line of code myself.
The machine is a tool. Not a mind. Not a threat. A hammer that becomes whatever you build with it.
The building - the act of making something that did not exist - that is the point.
I've been wrong like 500x times more than the average person. That's not shame. That's the badge.
subtitle: In which the traveler discovers that the one who builds knows things that the one who merely uses can never understand.
